claim: The confederate states spoke Old English before the Civil War.

supporting.text: Old English was spoken from the 5th to the 12th century, long before the Confederate States existed.

attacks.text: Old English was spoken from the 5th to the 12th century, long before the Confederate States existed.
The claim might refer to a dialect derived from Old English, not Old English itself.
Even if derived, no dialect from Old English was spoken in the Confederate States as a primary language.
The Confederate States could have had communities preserving Old English as a heritage language.
There is no historical evidence of Old English being preserved in any form in the Confederate States.

supporting.text: By the time of the Civil War (1861–1865), English had evolved into Modern English, not Old English.

attacks.text: By the time of the Civil War (1861–1865), English had evolved into Modern English, not Old English.
Some isolated communities in the Confederate states may have retained archaic dialects resembling Old English due to historical isolation.
Linguistic records show no evidence of Old English being spoken in any form in the 19th century United States.
The term 'Old English' could be misinterpreted to refer to early American dialects rather than actual Anglo-Saxon language.
Historical linguistics clearly defines Old English as pre-1066 language, making such misinterpretation linguistically invalid.

supporting.text: Historical records and linguistic studies confirm that American English in the 19th century was a form of Modern English.

attacks.text: Historical records and linguistic studies confirm that American English in the 19th century was a form of Modern English.
Some isolated communities in the South retained archaic dialects that preserved features closer to Early Modern English.
Linguistic analysis shows these archaic dialects still diverged significantly from Old English in grammar, vocabulary, and pronunciation.
The term 'Old English' is sometimes colloquially misused to describe any antiquated form of English.
Academic linguistics strictly defines Old English as the language spoken before 1150, making such usage factually incorrect.

supporting.text: The Confederate States primarily used Early Modern and Modern English, as evidenced by their written documents and speeches.

attacks.text: The Confederate States primarily used Early Modern and Modern English, as evidenced by their written documents and speeches.
Some isolated communities in the Confederate States preserved archaic dialects that retained Old English features, as documented by linguistic studies.
These archaic dialects were extremely rare and not representative of the broader linguistic practices in the Confederate States.
The claim refers to formal state communications, which definitively used Early Modern and Modern English, not Old English.
Old English was extinct by the 12th century, making it impossible for the Confederate States to have spoken it.
